Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment and Convention ground nexus in refugee claim
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found not credible regarding past persecution
Evidence_Type: Tamil ethnicity, association with MV Sun Sea, sur place activities
Legal_Provision: Section 96 and Section 97 of IRPA, Article 1A(2) of the Refugee Convention
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution based on nationality and membership in a particular social group
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Mixed motives doctrine, sur place claim, credibility
Application_Error: Failure to consider mixed motives and nexus to Convention grounds
Review_Outcome: Decision set aside, remanded for redetermination
Evidence_Ignored: Evidence linking Tamil identity and MV Sun Sea voyage to risk of persecution
Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution, Convention refugee definition
Application_Factor: Sur place developments, ethnic background, travel history
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed initially, under judicial review remanded
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court
Decision_Review_Issue: Error in credibility analysis and failure to apply mixed motives doctrine
Governing_Rule_or_Provision: Article 1A(2) of the 1951 Refugee Convention, IRPA s. 96-98
Cause_of_Refusal: Credibility issues and failure to consider mixed motives doctrine
Evidentiary_Issues: Overlooked evidence on nexus between identity and persecution risk
Procedural_Fairness: Failure to properly assess all relevant factors may breach fairness
Credibility_Issues: Applicant's testimony deemed not credible by RPD
Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Challenge based on reasonableness of RPD decision
Jurisdictional_Focus: Canada, Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration matters
Relevant_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Refugee Convention
Procedural_Issue: Remittal due to error in law and fact
Omission_Type: Failure to consider relevant evidence and legal doctrine
